t: For the choir director: “Do Not Destroy.” A Miktam of David.
Do*pn you really speak righteously, you mighty ones? Do*ln you judge people fairly?
No,*ln you practice injustice in your hearts; with*ln your hands you weigh out violence in the land.
The*pn wicked go astray from the womb; liars*ln wander about from birth.
They*ln have venom like the venom of a snake, like*ln the deaf cobra that stops up its ears,
that*ln does not listen to the sound of the charmers who*ln skillfully weave spells.
God,*pn knock the teeth out of their mouths; Lord,*sln tear out the young lions’ fangs.
May*ln they vanish like water that flows by; may*ln they aim their blunted arrows.
Like*ln a slug that moves along in slime, like*ln a woman’s miscarried child, may*ln they not see the sun.
Before*pn your pots can feel the heat of the thorns — whether*ln green or burning — he*ln will sweep them away.
The*ln righteous one will rejoice when*ln he sees the retribution; he*ln will wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.
Then*ln people will say, “Yes,*ln there is a reward for the righteous! There*ln is a God who judges on earth!”
